2 survivors of suspected drug vessel will be sent to home countries, Trump says 
         By The Associated Press 
        
           Saturday, October 18, 2025 • 3:38 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         WASHINGTON — The two survivors of an American military strike on a suspected drug-carrying vessel in the Caribbean will be sent to Ecuador and Colombia, their home countries, President Donald Trump said Saturday. The military rescued the pair after striking a submersible vessel Thursday, in what was at least the sixth such attack since early September. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "It was my great honor to destroy a very large DRUG-CARRYING SUBMARINE that was navigating towards the United States on a well known narcotrafficking transit route," Trump said in a social media post. "U.S. Intelligence confirmed this vessel was loaded up with mostly Fentanyl, and other illegal narcotics." The Republican president said two people onboard were killed — one more than was previously reported — and the two who survived are being sent to their home countries "for detention and prosecution." The repatriation avoids questions for the Trump administration about what the legal status of the two would have been in the U.S. justice system. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       With Trump's confirmation on his Truth Social platform of the death toll, that means U.S. military action against vessels in the region have killed at least 29 people. The president has justified the strikes by asserting that the United States is engaged in an "armed conflict" with drug cartels. He is relying on the same legal authority used by the George W. Bush administration when it declared a war on terrorism after the Sept. 11 attacks and is treating the suspected traffickers as if they were enemy soldiers in a traditional war.

articles.title: These Voters Want to Overturn Missouri's New Gerrymandered Congressional Map
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Missouri has become a flashpoint in the national redistricting battle following a Republican-led effort to gerrymander its congressional map, which targets longtime Democratic Representative Emanuel Cleaver II's Kansas City district. The map, signed into law by Republican Governor Mike Kehoe, has sparked widespread opposition from citizens and political leaders alike. Volunteers with the grassroots group People Not Politicians Missouri, led by Leann Villaluz, are collecting over 100,000 signatures to force a 2026 voter referendum on the map, arguing that their vote should not be diluted by partisan manipulation. The group faces legal challenges from state officials, including Attorney General Catherine Hanaway and Secretary of State Denny Hoskins, who claim the process violates constitutional provisions. Meanwhile, 15 Republicans, including Bill Allen and Jon Patterson, oppose the map, citing concerns about fair representation. Amezcua-Hogan, a local progressive, joins the effort, emphasizing that redistricting worsens existing community challenges like affordable housing and mental health access. Despite Republican support from lawmakers like Michael Davis, the controversy reflects a broader national debate over fair representation, democratic integrity, and the role of partisan politics in redistricting.
keyTakeAways: Missouri is one of the states following a Republican-led redistricting effort after President Donald Trump's national push in July 2025 to maintain Republican control of the U.S. House in the 2026 midterms.

The new congressional map, passed by a Republican-dominated Missouri legislature and signed by Governor Mike Kehoe, targets Democratic Representative Emanuel Cleaver II's district in Kansas City, leading to widespread opposition.
A group called People Not Politicians Missouri, led by volunteer Leann Villaluz, is collecting signatures to force a voter referendum to determine whether to keep or reject the new map.
The group has collected over 100,000 signatures and is still gathering more, aiming to reach 106,000 by December 11, 2025, to qualify for a 2026 referendum.

The state's Attorney General Catherine Hanaway and Secretary of State Denny Hoskins have challenged the referendum process, claiming it violates constitutional provisions and that signatures were gathered prematurely.
The executive director of People Not Politicians Missouri, Richard von Glahn, asserts that the group began collecting signatures before state approval and that the process is constitutionally valid.

Rebeca Amezcua-Hogan, a progressive running for Kansas City Council, opposes the redistricting, arguing it dilutes representation and worsens existing challenges like affordable housing and mental health access.

While the map passed easily in the Republican-controlled legislature, 15 Republicans, including Speaker Jon Patterson and Representative Bill Allen, voted against it, citing concerns over fair district representation.
Michael Davis, a Republican lawmaker and member of the Freedom Caucus, supports the map as a way to send a conservative message to D.C. and ensure Republican control of Congress.
The Democratic National Committee has joined the effort, providing staff and financial support to the referendum campaign.

articles.content:
These voters want to overturn Missouri's new gerrymandered congressional map 
         By Savannah Hawley-Bates 
        
           Saturday, October 18, 2025 • 9:21 AM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  Weekend Edition Sunday 
        
      

         KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Lately, on any given day, you'll find Leann Villaluz knocking on doors around Kansas City to get people to sign a petition that would let voters decide the fate of the state's new congressional map. "There's a sense of resentment, even to regular voters who aren't as involved," Villaluz says. "We have to pick up the slack for representatives who have been elected to do their simple duty and carry out the will of the voters. Instead, they think that we don't know what's best for ourselves." Missouri is the second state in the country, alongside Texas, to gerrymander its congressional map after President Donald Trump set off a  nationwide redistricting battle  in July to try to maintain control of the U.S. House in the 2026 midterms. Multiple other states, including North Carolina, Indiana, Florida, Ohio and Kansas could soon follow. California is trying to counter the Republican effort by  redistricting in favor of Democrats , if voters pass a constitutional amendment next month. Missouri's Republican Governor, Mike Kehoe, signed the new map into law late last month. The state had six Republicans and two Democrats in Congress, but the new plan targets longtime Democratic Rep. Emanuel Cleaver II's seat in Kansas City. But with Villaluz and about 3,000 other volunteers, a group called People Not Politicians Missouri is working to overturn the state's new map. If they're successful in getting more than 106,000 signatures across the state by December 11, a referendum will go on the ballot in 2026 for voters to decide whether to want to keep or reject it. The group says it's already gathered more than 100,000 signatures and is still collecting more. If they get the signatures they need, the referendum would stall the map until voters weigh in next year. Villaluz says everyone she's spoken to has been excited to sign. She's visited five neighborhoods so far around Kansas City, which would be split into three Republican-leaning districts under the new map. Villaluz even took her petition to the recent  Chappell Roan concert  to get signatures. "Just about anyone that stops and hears what the petition is about is ready and willing to sign," Villaluz says. "Whatever your vote is, it's going to be diluted with the maps, and nobody wants that." Missouri attorney general and secretary of state fight back  Not only does People Not Politicians Missouri have to gather enough signatures, it also has to take on pushback from top state election officials. The state's Attorney General Catherine Hanaway  filed a lawsuit in federal court  arguing that a referendum on redistricting violates both the U.S. and Missouri constitutions. Missouri Secretary of State Denny Hoskins did approve the group's referendum petition this week after  initially rejecting it . But in a press release, Hoskins claims that none of the signatures gathered before his approval date are valid. "The process is clear," Hoskins said in the release. "Every Missourian deserves confidence that ballot measures follow the law — not out-of-state agendas or confusion campaigns. Missouri values fairness and integrity, and this process reflects that." The executive director of People Not Politicians Missouri, Richard von Glahn, said in a statement that Hoskins is "deliberately spreading misinformation for political purposes," and that, according to the state constitution, the group was allowed to begin gathering signatures before the secretary of state's approval. "Our campaign has gathered signatures at a historic pace — I've never seen Missourians unite and mobilize this quickly," von Glahn said in the statement. "We will not be intimidated or distracted. This referendum will qualify, and Missourians — not politicians — will decide the future of fair representation in our state." The  Democratic National Committee  has joined the referendum effort and is contributing more staff and money to the cause. A  slew of lawsuits  have also been filed challenging the new districts. A legal effort, too  Rebeca Amezcua-Hogan is one of the plaintiffs in a lawsuit that seeks to block Hoskins from using the map to hold a congressional primary or general election and argues mid-decade redistricting without a new census is unconstitutional. "My own voting power would be watered down," Amezcua-Hogan says. "I would feel like I'm not being represented. And I think that at least personally, for the issues that are close to my heart that I've been working on for years, it would be incredibly discouraging." Amezcua-Hogan is running as a progressive for the Kansas City Council. The area she wants to represent would be split into three different congressional districts if the new map holds. When she talks to voters for her campaign, Amezcua-Hogan is also gathering signatures for the referendum effort. She says Kansas City is already competing for federal resources and splitting it up into three districts will only make that more difficult. "Kansas City is already at a point where we're dealing with lack of affordable housing, lack of mental health resources, lack of transportation," says Amezcua-Hogan. "It already feels like we're fighting an uphill battle, and that uphill battle is only going to get worse." Most, but not all Republicans, are on board Missouri's new congressional map easily passed the Republican-dominated Missouri Legislature in its week-long special session. Michael Davis represents a suburb south of Kansas City and is one of the lawmakers who championed the new map. He's part of the state's Freedom Caucus, a group of Republican legislators who aim to push the party further to the right. Davis says Missourians elected Republican lawmakers because they trust them to do what they think is best with redistricting. "We should send a conservative message to D.C.," Davis says. "The best way to do that is by sending seven Republicans who are going to ensure that Republicans keep control of the U.S. House of Representatives." But 15 Republicans — including Jon Patterson, the speaker of the Missouri House — voted against the map in the state legislature. Nearly all of them are from parts of the state targeted by redistricting or in areas that would be moved into new districts. Republican state Rep. Bill Allen represents a part of Kansas City's northland that is evenly split between parties. He opposes mid-decade redistricting and said he was disappointed that Missouri seemed to follow Texas and Trump's lead in doing so. "I think I heard from one or two constituents that wanted me to vote in favor, and almost every other one that I heard was in opposition," Allen says. "The job of the representative is to represent the district, not the party, certainly not the president. Just the district that I represent, the 39,000 people. Their will is my responsibility." Villaluz says she plans to keep gathering signatures for the next two months, until the group finds out if it has done enough to put redistricting on the ballot and potentially reverse Missouri's gerrymandered map. "I feel that Missouri is used as a guinea pig by the GOP," says Villaluz. "They think that the average Missouri voter is dumber than we are, and they think that they can get away with a lot more here in a red flyover state, but that's not the case." Villaluz says voters across Missouri won't stand idly by, and she believes they'll get the last word. 
         
         Transcript 
         DON GONYEA, HOST:   At least six states, most of them led by Republicans, are pressing ahead with plans to redraw congressional districts ahead of the 2026 midterms. But in one of those states - Missouri - there's growing opposition to the move, as Savannah Hawley-Bates with KCUR in Kansas City now reports. SAVANNAH HAWLEY-BATES, BYLINE: Thousands of volunteers with a group called People Not Politicians Missouri are part of an effort to overturn the state's new congressional map. LEANN VILLALUZ: I want my vote to count and continue to matter. HAWLEY-BATES: Leann Villaluz is one of them. VILLALUZ: If I'm not represented fairly in a map that's drawn fairly and that we voted on, that silence is my vote. HAWLEY-BATES: She's going door to door in Kansas City to get people to sign a petition that would let voters decide whether to keep the new congressional map. VILLALUZ: Hi. I'm Leann, and I'm going around to Jackson County voters to sign a petition to... HAWLEY-BATES: The group says it already has the more than 100,000 signatures needed to force a referendum and is still collecting more. But the state's top election official disagrees and says they started gathering signatures too early. That's sure to wind up in the courts. If the group is successful, the referendum would stall the map until voters weigh in next year. Right now six Republicans and two Democrats represent Missouri in the U.S. House. But the state's new plan, which Republican Governor Mike Kehoe signed into law late last month, decimates the Kansas City district of longtime Democrat U.S. Representative Emanuel Cleaver II. Here's Kehoe introducing the new map in August. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) MIKE KEHOE: I appreciate President Donald Trump for raising the level of conversation on this matter. HAWLEY-BATES: The Democratic National Committee is contributing staff and money to the referendum effort, and there's been a slew of lawsuits to challenge the state's new map. Rebeca Amezcua-Hogan is a plaintiff in one of the lawsuits. REBECA AMEZCUA-HOGAN: Kansas City is already at a point where we're dealing with lack of affordable housing, lack of mental health resources, lack of transportation. HAWLEY-BATES: She's running as a progressive for the Kansas City Council. The area she wants to represent would be split into three different congressional districts if the new map holds. As she talks to voters for her campaign, she's also gathering signatures for the referendum effort. Amezcuz-Hogan says Kansas City is already competing for federal resources, and splitting it up into three districts will only make it more difficult. AMEZCUA-HOGAN: It would be incredibly discouraging because it already feels like we're fighting an uphill battle, and that uphill battle's only going to get worse. HAWLEY-BATES: The new congressional map easily passed the Missouri legislature, where Republicans have had a supermajority for years. Michael Davis is one of the lawmakers who championed the new map. MICHAEL DAVIS: We should send a conservative message to D.C. HAWLEY-BATES: Davis says Missourians elected Republican lawmakers because they trust them to do what they think is best with redistricting. DAVIS: The best way to do that is by sending seven Republicans who are going to ensure that Republicans keep control of the U.S. House of Representatives. HAWLEY-BATES: But 15 Republicans voted against the map in the state legislature. Nearly all of them are from parts of the state that would be most affected by redistricting. Bill Allen is one of those Republicans. He represents a district in north Kansas City that is split evenly between parties. BILL ALLEN: I think I heard from one or two constituents that wanted me to vote in favor, and almost every other one that I heard was in opposition. HAWLEY-BATES: Allen opposes mid-decade redistricting and was disappointed that Missouri followed Texas and Trump's lead by doing it. ALLEN: The job of the representative is to represent the district, not the party and certainly not the president. And their will is my responsibility. HAWLEY-BATES: Leann Villaluz, the volunteer, says she thinks voters will get the last word. VILLALUZ: Just about anyone who stops and hears what the petition is about is ready and willing to sign. Whatever your vote is, it's going to be diluted with the maps, and nobody wants that. HAWLEY-BATES: Villaluz plans to keep knocking doors for the next two months. That's when the group will find out if it's done enough to put redistricting on the ballot and potentially reverse Missouri's new congressional map. For NPR News, I'm Savannah Hawley-Bates in Kansas City.

articles.title: Trump announces tariffs and an end to U.S. aid to Colombia amid clash over drug trade
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump announced the termination of U.S. aid to Colombia and the imposition of new tariffs on Colombian exports, accusing President Gustavo Petro of enabling drug production and calling him an 'illegal drug leader.' The U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth claimed a strike on a vessel linked to the National Liberation Army (ELN) rebel group, though no evidence was provided. Petro strongly rejected these claims, accusing the U.S. of violating Colombian sovereignty, assassinating a civilian fisherman named Alejandro Carranza, and conducting illegal military strikes. Colombia, a long-standing U.S. ally and top recipient of foreign assistance, faces a deepening crisis as U.S. aid dropped from over $700 million to $230 million. Experts warn that this escalation risks undermining regional stability and military cooperation, especially during heightened tensions with Venezuela. The conflict reflects a broader U.S. strategy in Latin America focused on drug interdiction, but at the cost of strained diplomatic and military ties with key allies.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump announced the end of U.S. aid to Colombia and imposed new tariffs on Colombian exports due to allegations that President Gustavo Petro is failing to suppress drug production.
Trump referred to Petro as an 'illegal drug leader' and accused him of being 'unpopular' and 'lunatic,' claiming Colombia is a 'drug manufacturing machine.'
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced a U.S. strike on a vessel linked to the National Liberation Army (ELN) rebel group, without providing evidence or confirming the vessel's drug-related cargo.

Colombian President Gustavo Petro rejected Trump's accusations, asserting he is the main force fighting drug trafficking and accusing the U.S. of violating Colombian sovereignty and assassinating a civilian fisherman, Alejandro Carranza.
Petro accused the U.S. of conducting illegal military strikes, calling it an 'invasion' of Colombian territory and demanding international legal action.
The U.S. has previously reduced aid to Colombia, cutting from over $700 million to $230 million in the fiscal year ending September 2025, undermining military and security cooperation.
The ELN has denied involvement in drug trafficking and has offered to submit to international scrutiny, while Colombian authorities continue reporting seizures of drug labs and narcotics.

Experts like Elizabeth Dickinson from International Crisis Group warn that alienating Colombia, a key U.S. ally, at a time of heightened tensions with Venezuela, risks destabilizing regional security and military cooperation.
At least 32 people were killed in U.S. military strikes in the region since early September, raising concerns about civilian casualties and diplomatic fallout.

articles.content:
Trump announces tariffs and an end to U.S. aid to Colombia amid clash over drug trade 
         By The Associated Press 
        
           Monday, October 20, 2025 • 12:07 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         PALM BEACH, Fla. — The United States will slash assistance to Colombia and enact tariffs on its exports because the country's leader, Gustavo Petro, "does nothing to stop" drug production, President Donald Trump said Sunday, escalating the friction between Washington and one of its closest allies in Latin America. In a social media post, Trump referred to Petro as "an illegal drug leader" who is "low rated and very unpopular." The Republican president warned that Petro "better close up" drug operations "or the United States will close them up for him, and it won't be done nicely." Later in the day, Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One that Colombia has "no fight against drugs" and "they are a drug manufacturing machine" with "a lunatic" for a president. He said that he would announce new tariffs on Monday. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth also announced the latest U.S. strike on a vessel that was allegedly carrying "substantial amounts of narcotics." He said the vessel was associated with a Colombian rebel group — the National Liberation Army, or ELN — that has been in conflict with Petro's government. He did not provide any evidence for his assertions, but he shared a brief video clip of a boat engulfed in flames after an explosion on Friday. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Petro, who can be as vocal on social media as his American counterpart, rejected Trump's accusations and defended his work to fight narcotics in Colombia, the world's largest exporter of cocaine. "Trying to promote peace in Colombia is not being a drug trafficker," Petro wrote. He suggested that Trump was being deceived by his advisers, described himself as "the main enemy" of drugs in his country and said Trump was being "rude and ignorant toward Colombia." The Colombian Foreign Ministry described Trump's statement as a "direct threat to national sovereignty by proposing an illegal intervention in Colombian territory." Defense Minister Pedro Sánchez told reporters that the country "has used all its capability and also lost men and women fighting drug trafficking." Trump's latest broadside against Petro raises the possibility of an expanding clash in Latin America, where the U.S. has already increased pressure on neighboring Venezuela and its leader, Nicolás Maduro. American naval ships, fighter jets and drones are deployed in the region for what the administration has described as an "armed conflict" with drug cartels. Trump also authorized covert operations inside Venezuela. Unlike Venezuela, Colombia is a longtime U.S. ally and the top recipient of American assistance in the region. But coca cultivation reached an all-time high last year, according to the United Nations, and there has been fresh violence in rural areas where the government spent years battling insurgents before reaching a peace deal a decade ago. In September, the Trump administration accused Colombia of failing to cooperate in the drug war, although at the time Washington issued a waiver of sanctions that would have triggered aid cuts. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Colombia received an estimated $230 million in the U.S. budget year that ended Sept. 30, a drop from recent years that exceeded $700 million, according to U.S. figures. Petro, Colombia's first leftist president, has repeatedly feuded with Trump this year. Petro initially rejected U.S. military flights of deported migrants, leading Trump to threaten tariffs. The State Department said it would revoke Petro's visa when he attended the U.N. General Assembly in New York because he told American soldiers to disobey Trump's orders. Petro and Trump have also been at odds over American strikes on boats in the Caribbean. On Sunday, Petro accused the U.S. government of assassination, pointing to a Sept. 16 strike that he said killed a Colombian man named Alejandro Carranza. Petro said Carranza was a fisherman with no ties to drug trafficking, and his boat was malfunctioning when it was hit. "The United States has invaded our national territory, fired a missile to kill a humble fisherman, and destroyed his family, his children. This is Bolívar's homeland, and they are murdering his children with bombs," Petro wrote on social media. He said that he asked his country's attorney general's office to initiate legal proceedings internationally and in U.S. courts. The White House and the Pentagon did not immediately respond to requests for comment on Petro's accusations. Despite Petro's criticism, his government plans to prosecute the Colombian survivor of a more recent U.S. strike on a submersible that was allegedly carrying drugs. Another survivor was repatriated to Ecuador, where the Ministry of the Interior said he would not face charges after prosecutors met with him and determined that he had not committed any crimes within the country's borders. The ELN, which Hegseth said was the target of Friday's strike, has long denied any role in drug trafficking and offered to submit to the scrutiny of an international commission. It did not respond to Hegseth's announcement. Colombian authorities regularly report the dismantling of cocaine laboratories and the seizure of drugs believed to belong to the guerrillas. There have been seven U.S. strikes in the region since early September that the administration says are targeting alleged drug traffickers. At least 32 people have been killed. Trump said Sunday that Petro had "a fresh mouth toward America." He complained that drug smuggling continues "despite large scale payments and subsidies from the USA that are nothing more than a long term rip off of America." "AS OF TODAY, THESE PAYMENTS, OR ANY OTHER FORM OF PAYMENT, OR SUBSIDIES, WILL NO LONGER BE MADE TO COLOMBIA," he added. Elizabeth Dickinson, senior analyst for the Andes region at International Crisis Group, said "it is befuddling and profoundly unwise of the United States to alienate its strongest military partner in Latin America at a moment when tension between Washington and Venezuela are at its highest point in recent years." She said Washington and Bogota have long treated their relationship as foundational, but "that wisdom is being thrown out the window, with really catastrophic effects." Colombia lost significant U.S. funding when Trump slashed the U.S. Agency for International Development earlier this year. More cuts could affect military cooperation and undermine efforts to fight rebel groups. "If that is cut, we will see a strategic loss of capability for the Colombian military and police at precisely the moment when they're confronting the greatest security crisis in Colombia for over a decade," she said.

articles.content:
Why are so many rich Americans investing in British soccer teams? 
         By Robbie Griffiths 
        
           Updated Saturday, October 18, 2025 • 10:23 AM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  Weekend Edition Saturday 
        
      

         Nestled on Britain's south coast in the county of Dorset, Bournemouth is a quintessential English seaside town, known for its sandy beach and fish and chips. At the start of October, Bournemouth men's soccer team hosted Fulham, London's oldest professional soccer team, for a tightly contested Premier League match. But although these two soccer teams might seem entirely English, they are both actually owned by Americans. And they are not alone: teams like Liverpool, Chelsea, and Manchester United, who have fans around the world, also now all have American owners. In fact,  more than half  of the 92 teams in the top four leagues in England and Wales have some American ownership, while Americans are also investing in teams in Scotland and across Europe. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "It's a much more affordable option into a high level of major sport," explains Jim Frevola, Bournemouth's president of business operations. Frevola moved from America to Bournemouth three years ago to help run the franchise for billionaire owner Bill Foley. Frevola compares the prices of British soccer teams to franchises in sports like the NFL and NBA in America. "Teams are going for six, eight billion … where you could buy teams in the Premier League for a much more affordable opportunity," Frevola said. "And, it's the best league in the world of the best sport in the world." Since moving to Bournemouth, Frevola has been struck by the passion of English soccer fans. "I never thought sports was different… until I came over here," Frevola said. "It wasn't until two, three months of living here did I realize that this is their life … this is what people live and breathe for. That's special. That's unique." Health care and real estate investor Kevin Nagle is the owner of Huddersfield, a third-tier team in Yorkshire, which he bought two years ago. "I guess instead of saying the British are coming, we say the Americans are coming," Nagle joked. "I purchased it outright in a really short period of time, sight unseen," he added. "It wasn't until after the fact that I came to Huddersfield to see what it was like. And I was very, very happy." Nagle also owns a soccer team in California, Sacramento Republic. But like Jim Frevola, he says there's something special about the richness of British soccer history. "It's just amazing when we see a lot of our fans, because their great, great, great-grandparents were watching the team play," Nagle says. "Do we love our soccer in the U.S.? Yes. But do we have the traditions in the U.K.? Absolutely not."  The involvement of several U.S. celebrities has brought extra attention to British soccer teams. Actor Will Ferrell has invested in Leeds, rapper Snoop Dogg in Swansea, and basketball star LeBron James in Liverpool. Similarly, actor Michael B. Jordan has a stake in Bournemouth. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Some of the stars have made documentaries about their teams. First, Hollywood star Ryan Reynolds — who was born in Canada — and his fellow actor and producer Rob McElhenney made the documentary  Welcome to Wrexham  about their journey buying the Welsh franchise Wrexham, which is now in its fourth season. This year, ex-NFL player Tom Brady joined them with his documentary  Built in Birmingham , about becoming co-owner of Birmingham City Football Club. TV fiction has also boosted American interest in British soccer, particularly the  successful TV dramedy  Ted Lasso , about an American college football coach who is hired to manage a London soccer team. Starring Jason Sudeikis and Brett Goldstein, the show — which has won multiple Emmys — is set to release its fourth season next year. Christina Philippou, an associate professor in accounting and sport finance at the University of Portsmouth, said the celebrity involvement in many of the franchises can be attention-grabbing, it usually takes the form of a minority stake. "They are able to effectively use their status to enhance the image of the club and help bring in more external income particularly around commercial partnerships," Philippou said. She explained that while English football has seen investment from Russia and the Gulf countries over the years, the new U.S. owners have made their teams more commercial, as well as boosting women's football teams at many British franchises. "We've seen a little bit more investment in women's football within club level … part of [that] is American money because traditionally they've been more interested in women's football." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In the U.S., British soccer has a growing audience, with as many as 40 million fans, with many watching on CBS, says Ben Wright, chief commercial officer for the English Football League — which covers both England and Wales. Wright said interest in soccer in America grew noticeably during the pandemic. "It felt like … because people couldn't go out and about globally, they were watching a lot more," Wright said. Meanwhile, Lionel Messi, the Argentinian who many consider the greatest soccer player of all time, plays for the American Major League Soccer team Inter Miami. On top of that, next summer's World Cup is being held jointly by the USA, Canada and Mexico, which experts hope will only grow the sport. Some soccer fans back in Britain fear that American owners might want to make changes to their league, such as playing league games in the USA. But Bournemouth's business manager Jim Frevola says that although he is aiming to grow his team's fan base back in the USA, there are no plans for major overhauls. "I think there's maybe a misconception that American ownership wants to institute [big changes]," Frevola said. "I've heard crazy things like all-star games. That's never going to happen." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In a pub near Bournemouth's Vitality Stadium, most fans are in favor of their American owner Bill Foley. Supporter Ceri Morgan said that although the slightly increased ticket prices have been a drawback, the investment is clear to see. "The stadium looks a lot smarter now and we're getting an increased capacity next season," he said. His fellow life-long fan Dom Webb agreed. "It's been incredible. … We've got really solid foundations now, and it feels like the sky's the limit," he said. 
         
         Transcript 
         SCOTT SIMON, HOST:   Snoop Dogg, Tom Brady, LeBron James, Will Ferrell and Ryan Reynolds have all invested in British soccer teams. They're part of a trend. Half of English Football League teams are now partly or wholly owned by Americans. Imagine. NPR's Robbie Griffiths went out to a game to find out why. (SOUNDBITE OF OCEAN WHOOSHING) ROBBIE GRIFFITHS, BYLINE: Nestled on Britain's south coast in the county of Dorset, Bournemouth is a quintessential English seaside town known for its sandy beach and fish and chips. (SOUNDBITE OF FOOTBALL CHANT) GRIFFITHS: Tonight, Bournemouth men's soccer team, known as The Cherries, are hosting Fulham, London's oldest professional club, in a tightly contested Premier League match. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) UNIDENTIFIED ANNOUNCER #1: And your Cherries, AFC Bournemouth. GRIFFITHS: But there's a twist. Although these two soccer teams might seem as English as they come, they are both owned by Americans. And they are not alone. Teams like Liverpool, Chelsea and Manchester United, with fans around the world, all have American owners. JIM FREVOLA: It's a much more affordable option into a high level of major sport. GRIFFITHS: Jim Frevola is Bournemouth's president of business operations. He moved from America to Bournemouth three years ago to help run the club for billionaire owner Bill Foley. Frevola explains that it's more affordable for rich Americans to invest in smaller British soccer teams and work on growing them than to buy sports franchises back in the USA, comparing prices to the NFL and NBA. FREVOLA: Teams are going for $6 billion, $8 billion, where you could buy, you know, teams in the Premier League for a much more affordable opportunity. And it's the best league in the world of the best sports - the best sport in the world. GRIFFITHS: In fact, half of the 72 teams in the English Football League have some American ownership, and Americans are also investing in teams in Scotland and across Europe. There are so many U.S. owners of British soccer clubs that many of them are in a WhatsApp group where they compare notes. KEVIN NAGLE: Well, here's the thing. I guess instead of saying the British are coming, we say the Americans are coming. Right? NAGLE: It's just amazing when we see a lot of our fans because their great, great, great grandparents, you know, were watching the team play. Do we love our soccer in the U.S.? Yes. But do we have the traditions in the U.K.? Absolutely not. GRIFFITHS: The involvement of several U.S. celebrities has brought extra attention to British soccer teams. Actor Will Ferrell has invested in Leeds, rapper Snoop Dogg in Swansea, and basketball player LeBron James in Liverpool. Some have even made TV shows about their teams. (SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "WELCOME TO WREXHAM") RYAN REYNOLDS: (As self) To make a diamond, you have to have pressure. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) ROB MCELHENNEY: (As self) What could possibly go wrong? (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) CHANNING TATUM: (As self) I'm very much into this. (SOUNDBITE OF BELL) UNIDENTIFIED FANS: (Shouting) Yeah. REYNOLDS: (As himself) Football. MCELHENNEY: (As self) Football. GRIFFITHS: That's Hollywood star Ryan Reynolds and fellow actor and producer Rob McElhenney in their documentary about buying the Welsh franchise Wrexham. (SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "TED LASSO") JASON SUDEIKIS: (As Ted Lasso) And all you fellas need to do is believe it. UNIDENTIFIED ACTORS: (As characters) Ooh. UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR: (As character) Coach, no. (CHEERING) UNIDENTIFIED ANNOUNCER #2: The Cherries are heading to second in the Premier League. GRIFFITHS: In the driving English rain, Bournemouth come from behind to beat Fulham 3-1, and the crowd goes wild. Bournemouth supporters say as long as their team keeps winning, they will keep backing their American owners. Robbie Griffiths, NPR News, Bournemouth.

articles.title: China Accuses U.S. National Security Agency of Cyberattacks on National Time Center
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: China has accused the U.S. National Security Agency of conducting a sustained cyber campaign against its National Time Service Center, including data theft in 2022 and attempts to infiltrate key timing systems between 2023 and 2024. The attacks allegedly exploited vulnerabilities in messaging services of a foreign mobile phone brand, and China claims the time center, which provides standard time for essential industries, is at risk. While China asserts it has evidence and has taken steps to mitigate risks, the U.S. has not responded directly and previously portrayed China as the most active cyber threat to its systems. This incident deepens existing geopolitical tensions between the U.S. and China across digital security, trade, and technology competition.
keyTakeAways: China accuses the U.S. National Security Agency of conducting cyberattacks on its National Time Service Center, targeting critical infrastructure such as network communications, financial systems, and power supply.
The attacks allegedly involved exploiting vulnerabilities in messaging apps of a foreign mobile phone brand (brand unspecified) to steal sensitive data from staff in 2022.
The U.S. National Security Agency reportedly used 42 types of 'special cyberattack weapons' to target multiple internal networks of the center between 2023 and 2024.
The National Time Service Center is responsible for generating and distributing China’s official standard time and supports essential sectors like communications, finance, transport, and defense.
China claims to have evidence of the attacks but has not provided it publicly, emphasizing that it has already guided the center to mitigate risks.
The U.S. Embassy did not respond directly to the allegations, but previously emphasized that China’s cyberattacks are the most active and persistent threat to U.S. government and corporate systems.
This incident adds to existing geopolitical tensions between China and the U.S. across trade, technology, and Taiwan-related issues.

articles.title: As they go unpaid, Capitol Police are a daily reminder for lawmakers of shutdown pain
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: During the ongoing government shutdown, Capitol Police officers are working without pay, having missed their first full paycheck on October 10, 2025. The situation has drawn attention from lawmakers, with concerns raised over the officers’ financial hardship, emotional toll, and lack of respect. Former Chief Terry Gainer describes the job as demanding, requiring officers to balance enforcement with hospitality. Union Chair Gus Papathanasiou and Representative Joe Morelle have called for action to end the shutdown and restore pay and dignity. Some lawmakers, like Senator Katie Britt, express sympathy for the officers, blaming political impasse, while others, such as Speaker Mike Johnson, claim support but are criticized for past actions, including delaying the installation of a memorial plaque honoring officers who defended the Capitol on January 6. The Trump administration has proposed using repurposed funds to pay law enforcement, but Democrats challenge the legality of this plan. A confrontation between Representative Nanette Barragán and an officer during a protest has further highlighted tensions, with the union demanding accountability. While officers remain committed 'for now,' one officer warns that morale may not withstand the full duration of the shutdown.
keyTakeAways: Capitol Police officers are working without pay during the government shutdown, directly impacting their financial stability and personal lives.
The officers face both physical and emotional strain, including threats of violence and public insensitivity from lawmakers, which undermines morale and job satisfaction.

Lawmakers, including both Democrats and Republicans, have expressed mixed reactions — some acknowledging the officers’ sacrifice, others showing disregard through actions like failing to oppose pardons or delay in installing a memorial plaque.
The Trump administration has proposed repurposing funds to pay federal law enforcement during the shutdown, though Democrats question the legality of such measures.
Capitol Police Chief Michael Sullivan and Union Chair Gus Papathanasiou have called for urgent action to end the shutdown and restore pay and respect for the force.

A former chief, Terry Gainer, emphasizes the demanding nature of the job, requiring officers to be both aggressive enforcers and welcoming hosts, making the situation even more difficult under current conditions.

Representatives like Joe Morelle and Nanette Barragán highlight the lack of negotiation and growing tension, with some incidents of confrontation raising concerns about officer safety and professionalism.

articles.content:
As they go unpaid, Capitol Police are a daily reminder for lawmakers of shutdown pain 
         By Sam Gringlas 
        
           Saturday, October 18, 2025 • 5:00 AM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  Morning Edition 
        
      

         Most of the effects of the ongoing government shutdown are far-removed from the halls of Congress. But the situation facing one group of federal employees who are working without pay is difficult for lawmakers to overlook: The Capitol Police officers who protect them every day. The officers missed their first full paycheck Oct. 10th. "They're asked to be everything to everybody," said Terry Gainer, a former Capitol Police chief. "You need to be ready at the drop of a hat to take very aggressive enforcement action, but you also have to be a person who will welcome visitors and be a tour guide." Gainer says the job is tougher than ever, as public officials face growing threats and violence. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Gesturing toward two officers guarding the ornate Senate Reception Room, Sen. Katie Britt, R-Ala., says she feels for the force's more than 2,000 officers and that Democrats are to blame for the impasse. "These men and women are paying the price," Britt said. "It's absolutely selfish and ridiculous. It's heartbreaking. People have mortgages, they have families." Officer Gus Papathanasiou, the Capitol Police union chair, called on lawmakers last week to end the shutdown, writing in a statement that "Banks and landlords do not give my officers a pass." Rep. Joe Morelle, D-N.Y., who sits on the House committee that oversees the force, says he has kept in touch with Papathanasiou and Capitol Police Chief Michael Sullivan. "What I find really strange is that there doesn't seem to be any negotiation going on at all and yet we're walking among people who are directly impacted by this," Morelle said. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The Trump administration has signaled  plans to repurpose funds  to pay federal law enforcement during the shutdown, though Democrats have questioned the legality of the moves. "I'm not unhappy with that result if it's the case," Morelle said. "But I'm still mindful of the fact that what the president is talking about, whether it's military troops or law enforcement, it's patently illegal," he said. Morelle says the missed checks are not the only slight, saying officers felt stung when some GOP lawmakers did not oppose  President Trump's pardons of rioters  who attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6th. He notes a Jan. 6 memorial plaque honoring officers who defended the Capitol  is still uninstalled  on Capitol Hill, despite a federally-mandated deadline. "We've always stood with Capitol police and law enforcement and we've shown that in word and deed," House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., told reporters last week. "All of a sudden after all of these issues where they have been frankly insulting to members of the Capitol Police, now they're going to say, 'Oh well, we really care about them," Morelle said. Gainer, the former Capitol Police chief, said officers continue to do their jobs with professionalism, but each slight makes it more difficult to convince them that the long hours and personal risk are worth staying for. Last week, Rep. Nanette Barragán, D-Calif.,   briefly clashed with an officer  during a protest, prompting the Capitol Police union to demand an apology. Barragán said the officer grabbed her as she tried to enter Johnson's office. "One of the skill sets we require of police officers is your ability to remember, because you're good witnesses," Gainer said. "So your memory doesn't get erased, but what you try to do is reset the clock." Asked this week whether they were holding up during the shutdown, a group of officers said they were — "for now." But one officer had an addendum to that assessment. "Give it a month, maybe not," he said.

Published: 2025-10-20T00:44:41+00:00

ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) — President  Donald Trump  said Sunday that the United States could purchase Argentinian beef in an attempt to bring down prices for American consumers. “We would buy some beef from Argentina,” he told reporters aboard Air Force One during a flight from Florida to Washington. “If we do that, that will bring our beef prices down.” Trump promised earlier this week to address the issue as part of his efforts to keep inflation in check. U.S. beef  prices have been stubbornly high  for a variety of reasons, including drought and reduced imports from Mexico due to a flesh-eating pest in cattle herds there. Trump has been working to help  Argentina bolster its collapsing currency  with a $20 billion credit swap line and additional financing from sovereign funds and the private sector ahead of midterm elections for his close ally, President Javier Milei.

articles.title: Centrist Rodrigo Paz wins Bolivia's presidential runoff, topping right-wing rival
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator with no prior national prominence, won Bolivia's presidential runoff election with 54% of the vote, defeating right-wing candidate Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga, who received 45%. The victory marks a decisive break from the 20-year rule of the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party, which voters criticize for economic mismanagement and unbridled spending. Paz, backed by a coalition of working-class and rural voters, including Indigenous Aymara communities, promises to dismantle Bolivia’s fixed exchange rate and fuel subsidies while gradually implementing market reforms to avoid a deep recession. His running mate, ex-police officer Edman Lara, gained massive popularity through social media anti-corruption activism, adding a populist edge to the campaign. However, Paz faces immense economic challenges, including a severe U.S. dollar shortage, inflation at 23%, and fuel scarcity, requiring urgent action to stabilize imports and restore currency confidence. Despite pledges to avoid the IMF, his fiscal plans have been criticized as vague, and many voters remain skeptical of his ability to deliver real change. The election reflects a clear class and regional divide, with Paz gaining support in the Andean highlands and Cochabamba, while Quiroga remains strong in the wealthy agricultural region of Santa Cruz.
keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator, won Bolivia's presidential runoff with 54% of the vote, defeating right-wing candidate Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga with 45%.
Paz's victory reflects widespread public dissatisfaction with the 20-year rule of the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party and its economic mismanagement.

Paz and his running mate Edman Lara, a former police officer known for anti-corruption activism on TikTok, appeal to working-class and rural voters disillusioned with MAS's spending and wary of radical free-market reforms.

Paz plans to end the fixed exchange rate, phase out fuel subsidies, and reduce public investment, while maintaining MAS-style social benefits and adopting a gradual reform approach to avoid economic collapse.
The economy is in crisis: inflation is at 23%, fuel is scarce, and Bolivia faces a shortage of U.S. dollars since 2023, making foreign currency reserves and import stability urgent challenges.

Paz has pledged to avoid the IMF and instead use anti-corruption measures and restored currency confidence to attract dollar savings, but his fiscal promises have drawn criticism as vague and potentially unsustainable.

Paz’s rise as a political outsider, despite a lack of national prominence prior to the election, signals a shift in political dynamics in Bolivia, with a strong base among Indigenous and working-class populations.
Lara, though inexperienced, gained significant popularity through social media and grassroots activism, and many voters believe he will play a more active role in governance than Paz.

The election reflects a clear class divide: Quiroga’s base is in wealthy agricultural regions like Santa Cruz, while Paz’s base is in Indigenous and working-class areas such as the Andean highlands and Cochabamba.

articles.content:
Centrist Rodrigo Paz wins Bolivia's presidential runoff, topping right-wing rival 
         By The Associated Press 
        
           Monday, October 20, 2025 • 1:19 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         LA PAZ, Bolivia  — Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator who was never a nationally prominent figure until now, won Bolivia's presidential election on Sunday, preliminary results showed, galvanizing voters outraged by the country's economic crisis and frustrated after 20 years of rule by the Movement Toward Socialism party. "The trend is irreversible," Óscar Hassenteufel, the president of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal, said of Paz's lead over his rival, former right-wing President Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga. Paz won 54% of the votes, early results showed, versus Quiroga's 45%. Paz took the podium Sunday night flanked by his wife, María Helena Urquidi, and four adult children. The hotel ballroom in Bolivia's capital of La Paz went wild, with people shouting his name and holding phones aloft. "Today, Bolivia can be certain that this will be a government that will bring solutions," he told supporters. "Bolivia breathes winds of change and renewal to move forward." Shortly after the results came in, Quiroga conceded to Paz. "I've called Rodrigo Paz and wished him congratulations," he said in a somber speech, prompting jeers and cries of fraud from the audience. But Quiroga urged calm, saying that a refusal to recognize the results would "leave the country hanging." "We'd just exacerbate the problems of people suffering from the crisis," he said. "We need a mature attitude right now." Paz and his popular running mate, ex-police Capt. Edman Lara, gained traction among working-class and rural voters disillusioned with the unbridled spending of the long-ruling Movement Toward Socialism, or MAS, party but wary of Quiroga's radical 180-degree turn away from its social protections. Quiroga's embrace of the International Monetary Fund — an organization that has long aroused political resentment in Bolivia — for a shock treatment package of the kind Bolivians came to know and fear in the 1990s also alienated more moderate voters. Paz's victory sets this South American nation of 12 million on a sharply uncertain path as he seeks to enact major change for the first time since the 2005 election of Evo Morales, the founder of MAS and Bolivia's first Indigenous president. Although Paz's Christian Democratic Party has the cushion of a slight majority in Congress, he'll still need to compromise to push through an ambitious overhaul. Paz plans to end Bolivia's fixed exchange rate, phase out generous fuel subsidies and reduce hefty public investment, redrawing much of the MAS economic model that dominated for two decades. But he says he'll maintain MAS-style benefits and take a gradual approach to free-market reforms, in hopes of avoiding a sharp recession or jump in inflation that would enrage the masses — as has happened before in Bolivia. Morales' effort to lift fuel subsidies in 2011 lasted less than a week as protests engulfed the country. Paz inherits an economy in shambles Paz's supporters erupted into raucous cheers and ran into the streets of La Paz, setting off fireworks and honking car horns. Crowds thronged a hotel downtown where Paz spoke, some shouting, "The people, united, will never be defeated!" "We feel victorious," Roger Carrillo, a volunteer with Paz's party, said by phone from eastern Bolivia, where he was rallying a celebratory caravan. "We know there is work ahead of us but we just want to enjoy this moment." Behind the celebrations, Bolivia faces an uphill battle. Since 2023, the Andean nation has been crippled by a shortage of U.S. dollars that has locked Bolivians out of their own savings and hampered imports. Year-on-year inflation soared to 23% last month, the highest rate since 1991. Fuel shortages paralyze the country, with motorists often waiting days in line to fill up their tanks. To make it through even his first months, Paz must replenish the country's meager foreign currency reserves and get fuel imports flowing. Vowing to avoid the IMF, Paz has pledged to scrape together the necessary cash by fighting corruption, reducing wasteful spending and restoring enough confidence in the country's currency to lure U.S. dollar savings out from under Bolivians' mattresses and into the banking system. But Paz's stated reluctance to slam on the fiscal brakes — with promises of cash handouts for the poor to cushion the blow of subsidy cuts — has led to criticism. "It's just so vague, I feel like he's saying these things to please voters when fiscally it doesn't add up," said 48-year-old Rodrigo Tribeño, who voted for Quiroga on Sunday. "We needed a real change." An outsider with political experience Although Paz, the son of former President Jaime Paz Zamora, who was in office from 1989 to 1993, has spent more than two decades in politics as a lawmaker and mayor, he appeared in this race as a political unknown. The senator rose unexpectedly from the bottom of the polls to a first-place finish in the August vote. His party swept six of nine regional departments in the country, including the Andean highlands of western Bolivia and the large, coca-producing region of Cochabamba, winning over key swaths of Indigenous Aymara and working-class Bolivians that once comprised Morales' base. Paz's slogan of "capitalism for all" appealed to many merchants and entrepreneurs who flourished in Morales' heyday but later chafed against his high taxes and regulation. Quiroga, by contrast, carried the wealthier eastern lowlands of Santa Cruz, known as the country's agricultural engine. "There's a very clear class difference. For Quiroga, you have people who've been in politics and in the economic elite for a long time — businesspeople, agro-industrialists," said Verónica Rocha, a Bolivian political analyst. "With Paz, it's the opposite." An ex-cop shakes up the race The race looked to be a staid affair until Paz surprised everyone by picking Lara as his running mate. The charismatic young ex-policeman had zero political experience but gained fame on TikTok after being fired from the police for denouncing corruption in viral videos. Out of work, he sold second-hand clothes to get by and worked as a lawyer helping Bolivians come forward about corruption — a story that resonated with many former MAS supporters. Lara's fiery, populist promises of universal income for women and higher pensions for retirees frequently forced Paz into damage control, causing tension on the campaign trail. But for those who see Lara as divisive and hot-headed, there are plenty of Bolivians who say those traits connote authenticity in comparison to the other scripted, telegenic candidates. Lara struck an unusually conciliatory tone in his remarks after winning Sunday. "It's time to unite, it's time to reconcile," Lara told supporters after learning of his win, taking a more conciliatory tone than usual. "Political divisions are over." Many Bolivians interviewed Sunday said they voted for Lara as if he were at the top of the ticket. "Lara is the one acting more like a president than Paz. Many of us think Lara will end up running the country," said Wendy Cornejo, 28, a former Morales supporter selling crackers in downtown La Paz.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Fengshen Lashes Northern and Central Philippines, Killing Seven
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A tropical storm named Fengshen, locally known as Ramil, struck the northern and central Philippines over the weekend, killing seven people and forcing more than 22,000 residents to evacuate due to flooding and landslides. The storm, with winds up to 65 kph and gusts up to 80 kph, originated in Luzon and moved into the South China Sea, with forecasts predicting a trajectory toward Vietnam. Key incidents included a drowning in Roxas City, Capiz, and a fatal incident in Pitogo, Quezon, where a burned palm tree collapsed on a sleeping family. The Philippines, already recovering from recent earthquakes in central Cebu, faces recurring natural disasters, making it one of the world’s most disaster-prone nations.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Fengshen, known locally as Ramil, caused severe flooding and landslides in northern and central Philippines, leading to seven deaths and forcing over 22,000 people to evacuate.

The storm had sustained winds of up to 65 kph (40 mph) and gusts of up to 80 kph (50 mph), with one fatality due to drowning in Roxas City, Capiz, and another five from a falling palm tree in Pitogo, Quezon.
The storm moved from Luzon into the South China Sea and was forecast to head toward Vietnam, indicating regional weather patterns and cross-border impacts.
The Philippines faces frequent natural disasters, including typhoons, earthquakes, and volcanic activity, making it one of the world’s most disaster-prone countries.
The region was still recovering from recent earthquakes that killed over 80 people and damaged over 134,000 homes in Cebu, showing compounded disaster risks.

articles.title: China’s Fourth Plenum Prepares for 2026–2030 Economic Plan Amid Global Tensions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The fourth plenum of the Chinese Communist Party, set to begin on Monday, is a critical internal meeting where leaders including Xi Jinping will finalize the next five-year economic plan (2026–2030). Occurring amid rising trade tensions with the United States — particularly under former President Donald Trump’s policies — the meeting emphasizes China’s push for technological self-sufficiency, especially in artificial intelligence and advanced chips. Despite a stable growth forecast of around 5%, domestic challenges such as the collapse of China’s property sector, low consumer confidence, and overcapacity in industries like auto manufacturing remain significant. Experts suggest that while the plan will follow familiar patterns, bolder actions are needed to stimulate consumer spending. The full plan will be formally released at the National People’s Congress in March 2026, and the Chinese leadership remains focused on stability, legitimacy, and national power as core objectives.
keyTakeAways: China’s fourth plenum, a closed-door meeting of the Communist Party, is set to finalize the next five-year economic and strategic plan (2026–2030).
The meeting occurs amid heightened trade tensions between China and the United States, particularly under President Donald Trump’s trade policies.
Economic growth is expected to remain near 5%, though recent slowdowns and domestic challenges such as property sector collapse and low consumer confidence have weakened momentum.
A major focus is on achieving technological self-sufficiency, especially in artificial intelligence and advanced chip technologies, as a response to U.S. export controls.
Domestic challenges include stagnant consumer spending, overcapacity in industries (e.g., auto), demographic aging, and high youth unemployment (nearly 19% for 16–24 year olds).
The leadership emphasizes stability, legitimacy, and national power over short-term growth, often accepting economic inefficiencies for strategic goals.
Policy responses to boost consumption have been incremental (e.g., subsidies for childcare, appliance trade-ins), but economists argue bolder measures are needed.

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews gathered in New York City to protest Israel’s Supreme Court decision in 2024 to end a longstanding exemption from mandatory military service for religious Jewish men. The protest, organized with support from the Central Rabbinical Congress and encouraged by the two Satmar grand rebbes, reflects deep tensions between religious tradition and state policy. articles.title: Military Conflict Between South Korea and China Escalates Amid Joint Naval Exercises and Aerial Confrontation
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A military conflict between the Republic of Korea and the People's Republic of China has escalated dramatically since April 18, 2024. The situation began with joint naval exercises between South Korea and the United States, announced on April 20, 2024. This triggered a series of military responses from China, including maritime patrols in the East China Sea starting on April 23, 2024. On April 25, South Korea deployed additional fighter jets to its western coast in response to the rising tensions. A significant aerial confrontation occurred on April 26, 2024, near the border, involving fighter jets from both South Korea and China. As of April 27, 2024, the conflict continues with ongoing military actions, heightened diplomatic tensions, and a clear escalation in the regional security environment.

articles.title: China’s Communist Party Approves Draft Five-Year Development Plan Amid Economic and Security Challenges

articles.title: Ukrainians disappointed after Trump-Zelenskyy meeting fails to immediately secure Tomahawk missiles
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy described a tense but positive meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump, where Trump did not deliver on promises to send Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine, despite agreeing to a ceasefire along the current front line and emphasizing a desire to end the war. Zelenskyy criticized Trump’s failure to provide the missiles and expressed skepticism about Hungary hosting future Trump-Putin meetings, citing Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s obstruction of Ukrainian interests. The U.S. continues to show economic interest in Ukraine through projects like an LNG terminal in Odesa, nuclear energy, and oil, while Ukraine seeks to procure Patriot air defense systems through frozen Russian assets. Zelenskyy noted that although Putin’s demand for full control over eastern Donetsk and Luhansk remains unchanged, all parties appear to have moved closer to a possible war end, with Trump aiming to leverage his Middle East successes to push for a peaceful resolution.

Zelenskyy expressed skepticism about Hungary hosting future Trump-Putin meetings, criticizing Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban for blocking Ukraine’s interests.

Zelenskyy believes that the overall message from Trump is positive and that all parties have moved closer to a possible end to the war, though a final agreement remains uncertain.

The procurement of 25 Patriot air defense systems from American firms using frozen Russian assets is ongoing, but long production queues delay full delivery, prompting Zelenskyy to seek faster procurement through European partners.

articles.title: Trump Suggests Ukraine Give Up Donbas Territory; Drone Attacks on Russian Energy Facilities Escalate
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump suggested that Ukraine should concede territory, particularly in the Donbas region, to end the war, proposing a ceasefire at current battle lines. This comes after Ukrainian drones struck a major Russian gas processing plant in Orenburg, operated by Gazprom, causing a fire and disrupting gas intake from Kazakhstan. In response, Russia launched drone attacks on Ukrainian cities including Kharkiv and Dnipropetrovsk, with reports of civilian casualties and attacks using modified weapons like the UMPB-5R. Ukraine claims to have also attacked a Russian oil refinery in Novokuibyshevsk, operated by Rosneft. Meanwhile, Trump did not commit to providing Ukraine with long-range Tomahawk missiles during his meeting with President Zelenskyy, raising concerns about U.S. military support. The article highlights a complex and escalating conflict involving territorial compromise, drone warfare, and civilian harm, with both sides targeting critical energy infrastructure.

Russia retaliated with drone attacks and modified aerial bombs targeting Ukrainian cities, including Lozava and Shakhtarske, and reportedly attacked a key Russian oil refinery in Novokuibyshevsk.

The U.S. president expressed openness to peace negotiations where Ukraine might have to give up territory, contradicting Kyiv’s hopes for full territorial restoration and the provision of advanced weapons like Tomahawk missiles.

articles.title: Rodrigo Paz wins presidential runoff, becoming Bolivia’s first conservative leader in decades
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator and former political outsider, has won the 2025 Bolivian presidential runoff with 54.5% of the vote, defeating former President Jorge ‘Tuto’ Quiroga, marking Bolivia’s first conservative leadership in decades. This victory comes after nearly two decades of Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) rule and amid a severe economic crisis marked by record inflation, fuel shortages, and a critical U.S. dollar shortage. Paz’s appeal lies with rural and working-class voters, especially Indigenous populations, who are disillusioned with MAS’s economic model and inflation. His running mate, ex-police officer Edman Lara, gained traction through social media activism and anti-corruption messaging. Paz plans to dismantle the fixed exchange rate, end fuel subsidies, and reduce public spending, though critics argue his policies are vague and potentially destabilizing. Despite pledging to avoid IMF bailouts, he faces a difficult path to restore foreign currency reserves and economic stability. The U.S. State Department has welcomed the new administration, signaling a potential revival of diplomatic ties. This election reflects a deep ideological and economic shift in Bolivia, with voters rejecting the MAS legacy and embracing a more market-oriented, conservative approach under Paz’s leadership.
keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz has won the Bolivian presidential runoff, becoming the country’s first conservative leader in decades.
Paz’s victory marks a major political transformation after 20 years of MAS rule, signaling a shift away from socialist economic policies.
Paz won 54.5% of the votes in the runoff against Jorge ‘Tuto’ Quiroga, who received 45.5%.
Paz’s campaign appeal came from rural and working-class voters disillusioned by inflation and fuel shortages.
Paz’s running mate, ex-cop Edman Lara, brought a new political energy with viral social media presence and anti-corruption messaging.

articles.title: Supreme Court to Consider Gun Ownership Rights for Marijuana Users
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to consider whether individuals who regularly smoke marijuana can legally own firearms, following a case revived by the Trump administration involving Texas man Ali Danial Hemani. Hemani was originally charged with a felony for possessing a gun in his home while being a regular marijuana user, and the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that a federal ban on gun ownership for drug users is unconstitutional under the Supreme Court’s 2022 expanded interpretation of the Second Amendment. The Justice Department has appealed this decision, asserting that such a ban is justified due to public safety risks, citing FBI findings of drugs and a gun in Hemani’s home. Hemani’s legal team argues the law unfairly criminalizes millions of Americans, as approximately 20% of U.S. adults have used marijuana, and half of U.S. states have legalized recreational use. This case represents a key test of how the Supreme Court’s new firearm rights framework applies to drug use, with broader implications for gun ownership policies and constitutional interpretation.
keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court is considering whether people who regularly smoke marijuana can legally own guns, marking a direct application of the 2022 expanded Second Amendment interpretation.
The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a Texas man charged with a felony for possessing a gun in his home while being a regular marijuana user.
The Justice Department argues that the blanket ban on drug users from owning guns is justified due to public safety risks, citing FBI findings of guns and cocaine in Hemani’s home.
Hemani’s attorneys claim the law is unconstitutional because it risks criminalizing millions of Americans who have used marijuana, noting that about 20% of U.S. adults have tried pot.
The case reflects broader tensions between conservative interpretations of the Second Amendment and government efforts to regulate firearm access based on drug use.
The appellate courts previously ruled that the law violates the Supreme Court’s expanded gun rights framework, leading to a reversal by the federal government via appeal.

articles.title: Plan to fire artillery over a highway during Vance visit irks California’s Newsom
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: During a live-fire exercise at Camp Pendleton to commemorate the 250th birthday of the U.S. Marine Corps, a 155 mm artillery round prematurely detonated overhead, sending metal shrapnel that damaged a California Highway Patrol vehicle and struck an officer’s motorcycle. The incident occurred on Saturday, prompting Governor Gavin Newsom to close a 17-mile stretch of Interstate 5 for safety. Despite the Marine Corps asserting that the exercise was safe and within protocols, a possible airborne detonation outside the designated area led to the immediate suspension of firing. No injuries were reported, but an investigation has been launched. Vice President JD Vance observed the drills, which sparked bipartisan controversy over public safety and political risk-taking. The event underscored tensions between military readiness demonstrations and civilian safety concerns.

articles.title: Chargers Fall to Colts in Injury-Riddled Loss, Losing Key Players and Momentum
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Los Angeles Chargers suffered a 38-24 loss to the Indianapolis Colts in a game marked by key injuries to their offensive line and backfield, including the season-ending absence of running back Najee Harris. With only a season-low 54 net rushing yards and three rushing touchdowns allowed by Jonathan Taylor, the Chargers struggled offensively and defensively. Quarterback Justin Herbert had a strong passing performance but turned the ball over in critical red-zone situations, contributing to the loss. Safety Derwin James Jr. took full blame, citing poor reads and team execution. Coach Jim Harbaugh acknowledged the Colts’ disciplined play and emphasized accountability, while noting the Chargers’ ongoing challenges due to injuries and a poor performance streak. The team is now preparing for a game against the Minnesota Vikings, underscoring their difficulty in maintaining consistency despite individual performances.

articles.title: Global Internet Outage Traced to Amazon Web Services DNS Failure
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A major outage of Amazon Web Services (AWS) in early October 2025 disrupted global internet services, including social media, gaming, finance, and streaming platforms. The failure originated in AWS’s domain name system (DNS) in the US-EAST-1 region and led to over 11 million user reports across more than 2,500 companies, affecting services like Snapchat, Roblox, Robinhood, Netflix, and Disney+. Even Amazon’s own products, such as Ring and Alexa, were impacted. Experts noted that the incident is consistent with past AWS outages and is likely due to a technical failure rather than a cyberattack. The event highlights the fragility of modern digital infrastructure, where the failure of a single cloud provider can cascade across the internet and leave users unable to access critical services, emphasizing the need for resilience and redundancy in global technology systems.
keyTakeAways: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a global cloud outage affecting over 2,500 companies and a broad range of services, including social media, gaming, financial platforms, and streaming services.
The outage originated in AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which converts web addresses into IP addresses, disrupting internet connectivity for users worldwide.
DownDetector recorded over 11 million user reports, with users of Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, McDonald’s app, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, and Signal reporting issues.
Amazon's own services, such as Ring doorbell cameras, Alexa smart speakers, and Kindle, were also impacted, showing that even internal platforms are vulnerable to infrastructure failures.
The outage is not unprecedented — AWS has faced similar disruptions in 2017, 2020, and 2021, with the 2021 outage lasting over five hours and affecting a wide array of global businesses.
Experts like cybersecurity professor Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess note that such outages are typically due to technical issues, not cyberattacks, and are usually resolved within hours.

The incident underscores how modern society is dependent on a small number of cloud providers (like Amazon, Google, and Microsoft), meaning a single failure can have cascading effects across the internet.
Users often do not see the root cause — they only experience disruptions in services like Snapchat or Roblox — making it difficult to identify the source of the problem.

articles.title: Jalen Hurts Proves He’s a Top Passer with Spectacular Performance to Lead Eagles Over Vikings
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Philadelphia Eagles overcame a difficult start to the season by defeating the Minnesota Vikings 28-22 on Sunday, thanks to a stellar performance from quarterback Jalen Hurts. Hurts threw for 326 yards and three touchdowns, including a 79-yard catch by DeVonta Smith and a key 45-yard pass to A.J. Brown. Jalen Hunt also returned an interception for a score. The game marked a resurgence for the Eagles' struggling offense, which had been dormant prior. Carson Wentz struggled with interceptions and poor red-zone performance. The Eagles also lost several key players to injury, including center Cam Jurgens and defenders Azeez Ojulari and Jeremiah Trotter. The win improved the Eagles to 5-2, while the Vikings fell to 3-3. The Eagles are set to play the New York Giants next, while the Vikings face the Los Angeles Chargers.
keyTakeAways: Jalen Hurts delivered a standout performance, throwing for 326 yards and three touchdowns, including a 79-yard touchdown to DeVonta Smith and a 45-yard rainbow pass to A.J. Brown, helping the Eagles overcome a sluggish start.

articles.title: Amazon Cloud Outage Disrupts Global Internet Services
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A major outage of Amazon Web Services (AWS) in October 2025 disrupted internet services globally, affecting key platforms such as Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, and the McDonald’s app. The root cause was traced to a failure in AWS's domain name system, which converts web addresses into IP addresses. The outage began at 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and was reported to be recovering by 6 a.m., though full resolution took until midday. Experts note that such outages are typically due to technical issues, not cyberattacks, and are resolved within hours using established cloud infrastructure recovery protocols. This incident highlights the critical dependency of modern digital society on a small number of cloud providers, making widespread outages both common and highly disruptive to everyday online activities.

The outage was traced to issues within AWS's domain name system, which converts web addresses into IP addresses critical for internet functionality.
Over 11 million users reported problems across more than 2,500 companies, including major platforms like Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, and Disney+.
Even Amazon’s own services, such as Ring doorbells and Alexa devices, were affected, illustrating the deep integration of AWS infrastructure in everyday digital life.
The incident underscores the world’s growing dependence on a few major tech companies for cloud infrastructure, making widespread outages highly disruptive.
Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess note that such outages are typically due to technical failures, not cyberattacks, and are resolved within hours using established recovery processes.
This is not the first time AWS has faced major outages—previous events in 2017, 2020, and 2021 show a recurring pattern of infrastructure failure.
DownDetector tracked extensive user reports, confirming the scale and breadth of the disruption across global digital platforms.
